title: Assignment 1
text:
Here is the first assignment (drafting a research project framework):

Topic: bilateral investment treaties (BITs) and foreign direct investment (FDI)
Research question: What is the effect of termination of bilateral investment treaties on the foreign direct investment (FDI)?
Outcome variable is annual FDI inflow of a country
Hypothesis: termination of BITs should lead to a decrease in FDI inflow.

title: About myself
text:
About myself:
I am currently a PhD candidate in Public Policy and Political Economy program at the University of Texas at Dallas with a focus on quantitative methodology, in particular I am also interested in pursuing a minor in Geographic Information Systems program as an extended methodological tools for policy analysis.
My research topics include the political economy of foreign direct investment, investment and/or trade agreements among countries. Moreover, I am also keen on improving/developing my methodological skills by learning from great examples of some of the general political economy or economic debates such as income - democracy nexus, Basque’s terrorism impact on GDP per capita, etc.
My contact via email: mtd220000@utdallas.edu or tuanminh112093@gmail.com.

title: Income and Democracy: A Replication paper
text: In the famous paper about “Income and Democracy”, Acemoglu et al (2008) (henceforth, “AJRY”) criticized the modernization theory and proved that spurious relationship between income and democracy “disappears” when we control for country-specific factors and time effects. While there are some later papers confirming AJRY’s robust results, Cervelleti et al suggests there may be a significant heterogeneous income effect: positive income effect for former colonies and negative for non-colonies sub-group. My approach is to re-examine the robustness results of AJRY and Cervelleti et al (2014) at the same time with regards to (1) different dataset, (2) wider time interval, (3) different time frequency, (4) different measurement of democracy index, and (5) sub-samples. My result confirms AJRY robust results and possibly questions the significant heterogeneous effects of income in sub-samples by Cervelleti et (2014).

title: Income and Democracy: A Replication paper
section: Estimation results: pooled OLS vs. two-way FE
text:
Estimation results: pooled OLS vs. two-way FE
In Table 3, let us interpret the coefficients (level-log interpretation).
For both pooled OLS model, a 1% increase in GDP per capita results in approximately 0.008 point increase in both democracy index on average and ceteris paribus, and this is effect is statistically signification (p<0.01).
For both two-way fix-effects model, a 1% increase in GDP per capita results in approximately 0.0005 point increase in both democracy index on average and ceteris paribus, and this effect is statistically significant (p<0.05).
We should note that we are talking about a 0-1 scale democracy index, the value seems small but is considerable: for pooled OLS model, a 100% increase in GDP per capita will result in 0.8 point increase!
As the Table 3 shows, the pooled OLS shows statistically significant coefficient of GDP per capita, this effect loses much of its significance when we control for country fix-effects and time fix-effects. In particular, the coefficients of both two-way fix-effects model are still statistically significant (p-value < 0.05), their effects are substantively weak (close to zero). By comparing two index of democracy, we can hardly see any substantive and significant effect of income - this is as we expected.

The AJRY’s result is definitely: (i) robust to the change in frequency of data points, (ii) robust to different measurement of the democracy index, (iii) robust to the change of a whole new data source of GDP per capita, and (iv) robust to the wider time range (1960-2021). This confirms the external validity of AJRY’s paper.

title: Income and Democracy: A Replication paper
section: Estimation results in the sub-samples based on past colonial experiences
text:
Estimation results in the sub-samples based on past colonial experiences


Estimation results for colony/non-colony sub-group









Dependent variable:

Note:


p<0.1; p<0.05; p<0.01



For former colonies sub-sample, as the Table 4 shows, the effect of GDP per capita is positive (and significant only for liberal democracy index, not for electoral measure). However, we can see that the substantive effect is still low. For non-colonies sub-sample, the effect of GDP per capita is “negative” but we do not have strong evidence to reject the null hypothesis of null effect (i.e., their 95% confidence interval includes zero). With this evidence, we can conclude that AJRY’s result is still robust in the sub-group based on colonial experience. While Cervellati and collegues suggests there may be significant heterogeneous effects: positive income effect in former colonies and negative income effect in the non-colonies sample (Cervellati et al. 2014), our results prove that there is no strong evidence of heterogeneous effect of income in sub-samples. This result can be attributed to our annual frequency and different source of dataset and wider time interval (1960-2021), compared to Cervellati et al’s, this may raise the question of external validity of their finding.

title: Income and Democracy: A Replication paper
text:
Replication of Table 2 (plot only)
Let’s take a look at models 1, 2, and 5 from Table 2 with the 95% CI plot:









Remember that, DV: Democracy; IV: log Income/capita (t-1).
We can confirm that:


Pooled OLS shows that there is an effect of income on democracy.

After controlling for unit-specific time-invariant effects (i.e., conditional on the confounders/ close the backdoor path), the effects are gone (Two-way FE Model 2) or substantively small to neglect (Two-way FE Model 5).

title: Income and Democracy: A Replication paper
text:
Replication of Table 5 (plot only)
Table 5 Replication from Model 4 to Model 9 (excluding model 6 - Arellano-Bond GMM model). From Model 4 to 9, Acemoglu et al (2008) used instrumental variable with two-way fixed effects. For my interest, I will replicate only this part and exclude model 6.
Let’s plot the result of first stage. Note that, DV now is lag of log Income/capita (t-1), IV is the saving rate lagged by (t-2) or (t-3).









We see our instrumental variable saving rate is strongly correlated with the income. The authors proposed one possible channel (i.e., labor share): labor share also correlates strongly with income.
And, the second stage:









We do see that the income effect is predicted around 0. Moreover, labor share effect is also possibly null: the exclusion restriction may be upheld (i.e., “labor share” - a channel of saving rate - predicts “income” but not “democracy”). While we have never been able to “list out” every possible underlying channel, the authors tried their best to prove that income does not predict democracy at all.

title: Income and Democracy: A Replication paper
text:
Replication of Table 6 (plot only)
Table 6 Replication, from Model 4 to 9 (excluding model 5) Here I use plm package:
First stage:









We can see that trade-weighted GDP strongly predicts income, and the possible channel trade-weighted democracy also strongly predicts income.
And, the second stage:









Now, we can see that the lagged income is predicted to be close to zero. We know that IV method is inefficient and the standard error is wide. But again, this can be a (weak) evidence showing that income has null effect on democratization.
Again, the possible channel (trade-weighted democracy) seems like having null effect on democracy, which makes the exclusion restriction seems valid.

title: Assignment 5: Government data API
text:
(Not running)

# Start with a clean plate and lean loading to save memory
gc(reset=T)

# install.packages(c("purrr", "magrittr")
library(purrr)
library(magrittr) # Alternatively, load tidyverse
setwd("/Users/tuanminh/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Personal/Projects/Git2/data_collection/")
library(rjson)
library(jsonlite)
library(data.table)
library(readr)

gf_list = jsonlite::read_json("gov_api/search_results.json") # Download from government site
gov_df <- gf_list$resultSet |> dplyr::bind_rows()

gov_df$publishdate <- as.Date(gov_df$publishdate)

gov_top10 <- gov_df |>
  dplyr::arrange(dplyr::desc(publishdate)) |>
  dplyr::slice(1:10)

# Check
gov_top10[, c("title", "publishdate")]

## Extract URLs and IDs
pdf_urls <- gov_top10$pdfLink

if ("packageId" %in% names(gov_top10)) {
  pdf_ids <- gov_top10$packageId
} else {
  pdf_ids <- gov_top10$index  # fallback
}

## Directory to save (same as before)
save_dir <- "/Users/tuanminh/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-Personal/Projects/Git2/data_collection/gov_api/"

## Download function (same as govtdata01.R)
download_govfiles_pdf <- function(url, id) {
  tryCatch({
    destfile <- paste0(save_dir, "govfiles_", id, ".pdf")
    download.file(url, destfile = destfile, mode = "wb")
    Sys.sleep(runif(1, 1, 3))
    paste("Successfully downloaded:", url)
  },
  error = function(e) paste("Failed to download:", url))
}

## Download the 10 most recent
start.time <- Sys.time()
message("Starting downloads: Top 10 most recent documents")

results_top10 <- seq_along(pdf_urls) |>
  purrr::map_chr(~ download_govfiles_pdf(pdf_urls[.], pdf_ids[.]))

message("Finished downloads")
end.time <- Sys.time()
time.taken <- end.time - start.time
time.taken

print(results_top10)

title: Assignment 5: Government data API
text:
No direct JSON/CSV
GovInfo’s search page does not give you directly json or csv file to automate the search and download in the next step.

title: Assignment 5: Government data API
text:
Limitation of the search terms
It is hard to pinpoint the search terms to get the file we want. The date can vary a lot (e.g., year 1999 and recent year 2025) in the result of json file.

title: Assignment 5: Government data API
text:
Large files and slow downloading
We have to insert random sleep intervals to not look like a bot. This makes bulk retrieval time-consuming.

title: Assignment 1
text:
Assignment 1
This website is created using RStudio Quarto. The cosmo theme is used for professional look.
The navigation bar includes links for connecting author’s contents in different areas.

title: Research Projects
text:
I have a vested interested in developing my methodological know-how, especially quantitative approaches. Here are some examples of my paper and past class assignments (replication) as an attempt to learn & use STATA, R.

Mixed effects model (both random- and fixed-effects) evaluating the information processing of vulnerable groups and the outcome of adoption of health messages in COVID-19 (Dao and Lim 2022). The theoretical framework in use is based on Extended Parallel Process Model by Witte.
Two-way fix-effects with dynamic modeling based on income - democracy nexus with the replication of the famous Income and Democracy paper (Acemoglu et al. 2008) with (i) different dataset, (ii) time frequency from five-year to annual interval, (iii) longer time span from 1960 to 2022, (iv) checking for heterogeneous effect of income in sub-samples (countries with past 500-year colonial experience or not). Please find my replication paper here.
Synthetic control method: replication based on the famous paper on the effect of Basque’s terrorism on GDP per capita (Abadie and Gardeazabal 2003) with comments from an improved synthetic control, i.e., augmented synthetic control (Ben-Michael, Feller, and Rothstein 2021). Please find my replication paper here (update later).





References

Abadie, Alberto, and Javier Gardeazabal. 2003. “The Economic Costs of Conflict: A Case Study of the Basque Country.” American Economic Review 93 (1): 113–32.


Acemoglu, Daron, Simon Johnson, James A. Robinson, and Pierre Yared. 2008. “Income and Democracy.” The American Economic Review 98 (3): 808–42. http://www.jstor.org/stable/29730096.


Ben-Michael, Eli, Avi Feller, and Jesse Rothstein. 2021. “The Augmented Synthetic Control Method.” Journal of the American Statistical Association 116 (536): 1789–1803.


Dao, Minh Tuan, and Seunghoo Lim. 2022. “Fear of Disasters Within the Risk Communication Network of Foreign Students in Japan Amid the COVID-19 Pandemic Crisis: A Cohort Design.” International Journal of Disaster Risk Reduction 71 (March): 102808. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijdrr.2022.102808.

title: Assignment 2
text:
## Google Trends with R
install.packages("gtrendsR")
library(gtrendsR)
TrumpHarrisElection = gtrends(c("Trump","Harris","election"), onlyInterest = TRUE, geo = "US", gprop = "web", time = "today+5-y", category = 0, ) # last five years
the_df=TrumpHarrisElection$interest_over_time
plot(TrumpHarrisElection)
tg = gtrends("tariff", time = "all")

# Example: Tariff, China military, Taiwan 
# 
plot(gtrends(c("tariff"), time = "all"))
data("countries")
plot(gtrends(c("tariff"), geo = "GB", time = "all")) 
plot(gtrends(c("tariff"), geo = c("US","GB","TW"), time = "all")) 
tg_iot = tg$interest_over_time
tct = gtrends(c("tariff","China military", "Taiwan"), time = "all")
tct = data.frame(tct$interest_over_time)
plot(gtrends(c("tariff","China military", "Taiwan"), time = "all"))

title: Assignment 2
text:
Advantages

Manual: easy to use, quick comparisons.
gtrendsR: automated, fully reproducible

title: Assignment 2
text:
Disadvantages

Manual: manual download and limited reproducibility
gtrendsR: sometimes gives different date ranges or aggregation, requires R setup

title: Assignment 6: Text Analytics using Quanteda
text:
Summit Data: President Biden - President Xi





The Biden–Xi summit generated mostly informational tweets, as shown by the frequency plot dominated by basic terms like “biden,” “xi,” “summit,” and “virtual,” with China-related words appearing prominently.





The hashtag network shows two main themes: one focused on U.S.–China relations (#china, #americans, #fentanyl, #coronavirus) and another on human rights (#uyghurs, #tibetans, #humanrights).





The user network reveals several small, separate clusters—journalists, policy analysts, and even NBA-related accounts—indicating that discussion was fragmented rather than centered on a single influential group.
Overall, the summit sparked multiple parallel conversations rather than a unified or highly polarized debate.


US Presidential Inaugural Speeches
We will analyze total 60 inaugural speeches from 1789 - 2005 of 36 unique U.S. Presidents.





Across more than two centuries of inaugural addresses, several consistent linguistic patterns emerge. The relative-frequency plot of the term “American” shows that while most presidents use the term sparingly, some modern presidents—especially Clinton and Trump—use it more frequently when normalized by speech length, suggesting a rhetorical shift toward more explicit national identity framing in contemporary inaugurals. 



Top 10 Terms


The top-term comparisons for recent presidents highlight both common themes and individual emphases: Biden and Obama frequently invoke concepts such as “freedom,” “democracy,” and “people,” whereas Bush and Trump show a stronger emphasis on “America,” “nation,” and “great.” These differences reveal variation in tone and messaging even within the same historical era.





Finally, the overall word cloud summarizing the full set of 60 speeches shows enduring thematic anchors of presidential rhetoric—terms like government, people, states, country, great, and may dominate—reflecting long-standing concerns with governance, national unity, and civic duty. Together, these visualizations illustrate both the continuity of presidential messaging over time and the distinctive rhetorical signatures of individual presidents.


What is “Wordfish?”
Wordfish is a tool that helps us understand how texts differ from one another by placing them on a single underlying scale. Instead of telling the model what “left,” “right,” or any other dimension means, Wordfish simply looks at how often certain words are used in each document and figures out which texts tend to sound similar or different. Documents that rely on similar vocabulary end up close together on this scale, while those that use distinct language are placed farther apart. In other words, wordfish is an unsupervised method.





Earlier presidents, especially Eisenhower (1953, 1957), Kennedy (1961), Johnson, and Nixon (1973–1969,) cluster toward the lower end of the scale. This suggests that mid-20th-century inaugurals shared a more similar rhetorical style, likely shaped by Cold War themes, formal institutional language, and a more standardized presidential voice. Speeches from the 1980s onward shift upward, with Reagan, Clinton, Bush, Obama, and finally Biden and Trump occupying increasingly higher positions. The very high scores for Trump (2017 and 2025) and Biden (2021) reflect more distinctive modern rhetorical styles that rely on different vocabularies, emotional tones, or issue emphases compared to traditional mid-century speeches.
Overall, the plot shows a gradual movement from older, institution-focused rhetoric toward more polarized, personalized, or contemporary styles in recent decades.

title: Assignment 4: Webscraping
text:
# Load packages
library(rvest)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(stringr)
library(readr)


Attaching package: 'readr'


The following object is masked from 'package:rvest':

    guess_encoding

# Step 1: Scrape data from Wikipedia
url <- 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign-exchange_reserves'

wikiforreserve <- read_html(url)

# Extract all tables from the page
tables <- wikiforreserve %>% html_table(fill = TRUE)

# The first table is the main one with countries' foreign reserves
fores <- tables[[1]]

# Inspect column names
names(fores)

[1] "Country(as recognized by the U.N.)" "Continent"                         
[3] "Foreign exchange reserves"          "Foreign exchange reserves"         
[5] "Foreign exchange reserves"          "Foreign exchange reserves"         
[7] "Last reporteddate"                  "Ref."                              

head(fores)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  Country(as recognize…¹ Continent Foreign exchange res…² Foreign exchange res…³
  <chr>                  <chr>     <chr>                  <chr>                 
1 Country(as recognized… Continent Including gold         Including gold        
2 Country(as recognized… Continent millions U.S.$         Change                
3 China                  Asia      3,643,149              41,079                
4 Japan                  Asia      1,324,210              19,774                
5 Switzerland            Europe    1,007,710              13,935                
6 Russia                 Europe/A… 734,100                14,300                
# ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​`Country(as recognized by the U.N.)`,
#   ²​`Foreign exchange reserves`, ³​`Foreign exchange reserves`
# ℹ 4 more variables: `Foreign exchange reserves` <chr>,
#   `Foreign exchange reserves` <chr>, `Last reporteddate` <chr>, Ref. <chr>


Clean up the dataframe:

names(fores) <- c(
  "Country", "Continent",
  "Reserves_InclGold_USD", "Change_InclGold_USD",
  "Reserves_ExclGold_USD", "Change_ExclGold_USD",
  "LastReported", "Ref"
)

# Drop the first two header rows (non-country rows)
fores_clean <- fores[-c(1,2), ]

# Clean numeric variables
fores_clean <- fores_clean %>%
  mutate(
    Reserves_InclGold_USD = as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Reserves_InclGold_USD)),
    Change_InclGold_USD   = as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Change_InclGold_USD)),
    Reserves_ExclGold_USD = as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Reserves_ExclGold_USD)),
    Change_ExclGold_USD   = as.numeric(gsub(",", "", Change_ExclGold_USD)),
    LastReported = trimws(str_split_fixed(LastReported, "\\[", n = 2)[,1])
  )

Warning: There were 2 warnings in `mutate()`.
The first warning was:
ℹ In argument: `Reserves_ExclGold_USD = as.numeric(gsub(",", "",
  Reserves_ExclGold_USD))`.
Caused by warning:
! NAs introduced by coercion
ℹ Run `dplyr::last_dplyr_warnings()` to see the 1 remaining warning.

# Drop non-country rows and NAs
fores_clean <- fores_clean %>%
  filter(!is.na(Country), !Country %in% c("World", "Total", "Country(as recognized by the U.N.)")) %>%
  filter(!grepl("Country", Country))

# Inspect cleaned result
glimpse(fores_clean)

title: Assignment 4: Webscraping
text:
Examples

# Example use:
gdp <- c("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)")

wiki_gdp <- scrape_wiki_table(gdp, table_index = 3)
head(wiki_gdp)

title: Minh Dao’s Website
text:
Hi everyone,
My name is Minh Dao, currently I am a PhD candidate of PPPE program at UT Dallas with expected graduation in 2027.
My website includes some samples of my past projects and assignments for the current class of Fall 2025 - Methods of Data Collection and Production.
Updated November 2025.
